Award.AwardTitle: The Influence of Sociality in Cancer Treatment Decision-Making

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Carolyn Sargent of Washington University will research how transnational communications about disease generate therapy management group decision-making. The research will contribute to scientific understandings of how disease shapes social interaction and how meanings of illness acquire legitimacy and influence treatment decisions. Medical anthropologists have long emphasized the ways in which many treatment decisions are influenced not just by communications between doctor and patient, but also by a range of larger social networks. The research focuses on meanings and strategies about breast cancer among immigrants from the Senegal River Valley (Mali, Mauritania, Senegal) in Paris, France, an appropriate research context because of the robust and complex transnational decision-making networks that have emerged. Migrant communities such as these have proven to be an ideal social laboratory for exploring the formation of decision-making networks as these are typically spaces where a range of social relationships are observably emergent. Three central questions are posed: (1) how sufferers, families, interpreters and clinicians collectively and progressively define and manage cancer; (2) how social relations are restructured around the collective experience of cancer and how the symbolic importance of cancer figures into these reconfigurations; (3) how transnational meanings and strategies are continuously generated by means of cell phone and other communications. To investigate these questions, the researchers have designed a two-year study, to follow 40 women with breast cancer, as well as caretakers, clinicians and interpreters. Regular home visits will be conducted to assess kinship obligations, social hierarchies, and moral conventions, using semi-structured interviews and a mix of qualitative methods. Participant observation in women's immigrant associations will allow the researchers to assess popular representations of breast cancer and treatment modalities.

The broader impact of this research lies in its implications for public health policy and clinical practice. The research explores the impacts to medical treatment that arise when biomedical practitioners, patients, and families do not share a common language or core illness constructs and treatment expectations. It points to areas that merit attention to ensure that policies acknowledge the potential for serious disruptions in the provision of care to gravely ill patients when these issues remain unaddressed. The researchers' connections with clinicians and public health officials will facilitate the dissemination of research findings and produce relevant workshops, working papers, and publications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this research on sociality and cancer decisions in France, we focus on three central questions: 1) how do women with breast cancer and their families, comprehend and conceptualize this disease over time; 2) does the experience of breast cancer produce a "disrupted biography," in which the sufferer questions the meanings associated with their identity prior to the illness and seeks to reconstruct a sense of self and social relations as they proceed through treatment; and 3) how effectively do patients and physicians communicate about diagnosis, treatment, and eventual outcome of a breast cancer episode? 

Because French citizens have a constitutional right to health care, we also investigated  access to cancer treatment among diverse populations in Paris, to determine whether there is variability in institutional access by neighborhood. In addition, we interviewed 36 women in course of breast cancer interventions over a two-year period. In these interviews, we assessed changing understandings of the potential causes of breast cancer, treatment choices, and probable outcomes. We also observed six cancer specialists at three public hospitals in Paris, engaged in consultations with patients. By means of these observations, we were able to evaluate the clarity of clinical communication, the extent to which women asked questions of their doctors,  the reasons why some women chose not to continue treatment, and the role of family and friendship networks in caretaking and strategizing.  We also met with seventy leaders of community associations to gain a sense of public knowledge regarding cancer in general, and breast cancer in particular.  We were able to assess the impact of government initiatives to publicize the importance of mammography for early detection of breast cancer and successful management of the condition over time.

The intellectual merit of the research lies in the investigation of meaning-making, how non-specialists, when confronted with a serious and chronic illness, make sense of complex concepts and the necessity of decision making in the context of uncertainty. By following patients as they navigated the public hospital system, we were able to determine how social, political, and economic facets of everyday life shaped the experience of a cancer diagnosis. Our research results demonstrate that a life-threatening illness is likely to have especially problematic consequences for economically precarious households. In such instances, difficult decisions arise concerning whether to prioritize medical treatment, job security, housing, child care, or household income. Vulnerable families may experience a downward economic spiral as they attempt to manage the demands of hospitalization and cancer therapies while already living in a state of precarity.

The broader social impacts of this research lie in the area of medical ethics and clinical communication. The research findings indicate ways in which approaches to palliative care, advance directives, and informed consent might usefully be modified. The biomedical prioritizing of truth-telling also merits reflection, in light of the variation among patient populations in what is considered "appropriate" representations of "the truth." The research offers alternative understandings of that which is considered moral or right action in the context of serious illness.

The findings from this project therefore have implicatons for enhancing communication among physicians, other hospital personnel such as nurses and social workers, and patients. The results have the potential to clarify for clinicians those modes of explanation which are unlikely to be understood or considered appropriate by patients and families.
